enWisdom: The grave is better than poverty

Wisdom: أَلَا وَإِنَّ مِنَ الْبَلَاءِ الْفَاقَةَ وَأَشَدُّ مِنَ الْفَاقَةِ مَرَضُ الْبَدَنِ وَأَشَدُّ مِنْ مَرَضِ الْبَدَنِ مَرَضُ الْقَلْبِ
enWisdom: Indeed destitution is an affliction, and worse than destitution is sickness of the body, and worse than bodily ailment is the sickness of the heart
Adversity degrades morals and alienates friends

Wisdom: إِنَّ الْفَقْرَ مَذَلَّةٌ لِلنَّفْسِ مَدْهَشَةٌ لِلْعَقْلِ جَالِبٌ لِلْهُمُومِ
enWisdom: Verily poverty is disgracer for the soul, a confounder of the intellect, and a bringer of sorrows
He (‘a) said about the one whom he censured:  if he becomes poor, he despairs

Wisdom: ثَلَاثٌ هُنَّ الْمُحْرِقَاتُ الْمُوبِقَاتُ فَقْرٌ بَعْدَ غِنًى وَذُلٌّ بَعْدَ عِزٍّ وَفَقْدُ الْأَحِبَّةِ [الْأَحِبَّاءِ]
enWisdom: Three things break one’s spirit and cause downfall: poverty after wealth, humiliation after dignity and loss of loved ones

Wisdom: ضَرُورَةُ الْفَقْرِ تَبْعَثُ عَلَى فَظِيعِ [قَطْعِ‏] الْأَمْرِ
enWisdom: The plight of poverty impels one towards a despicable affair
Poverty disables the astute one from [presenting] his argument
The poor person is [like] a stranger (or is scorned) in his hometown
Poverty in one’s homeland is like being a stranger in it
The needy person is a stranger in his own homeland

Wisdom: لَيْسَ فِي الْغُرْبَةِ عَارٌ إِنَّمَا الْعَارُ فِي الْوَطَنِ الِافْتِقَارُ
enWisdom: There is no shame in being far away from one’s hometown; the only shame is being indigent in one’s one hometown
